labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix

issues.title: Should instance labels include the XOF that's used for key generation?
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: For example, `QSF-SHA3-256-ML-KEM-768-P-256` doesn't say that it uses SHAKE256 for the XOF. Should we?

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
I'm not sure that's right thought

``` 
ss = LabeledHKDF(pq_SS, trad_SS, pq_CT, pq_PK, trad_CT, trad_PK, label)
```

There's no "transcript" in there, unless you jam it into the label, but that's not required by the text? And I think that TLS has a well-defined concept of a "transcript", but I think it's less clear what counts as "transcript" for example if you have a JWT payload on an HTTP POST -- does "transcript" mean that the entire payload of the JWT should be included in the label? Or does "transcript" mean the entire sequence of HTTP messages exchanged so far on this connection? Obviously that's not what's intended, but might be how a non-cryptographer interprets the word "transcript". I don't have a better suggestion than "KitchenSink", but I don't think that "TranscriptHash" is the right connotation for protocols that aren't TLS.

issues.title: IANA Register HPKE KDFs?
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
The IANA "Hybrid Public Key Encryption (HPKE)" page has registries for KEMs, KDFs, and AEADs. Currently, the only KDFs registered are HKDF-SHA256/384512.

I believe that someone needs to register at least these two KDFs in the IANA registry before HPKE key derivation is truly supported:
- KDF(SHA3-256) — referring to Section 6.1 of FIPS202
- XOF(SHAKE256) — referring to Section 6.2 of FIPS202

This document seems a likely place for that registration. It may have the nice side effect that the names of the QSF-based KEMs can become shorter.

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body: Sorry no, the KDF and XOF's mentioned in this document are _entirely internal_ to the KEM schemes laid out here. These schemes are to be registered in HPKE KEM IANA, and any other HPKE KDF or AEAD usages are fully independent of the schemes laid out here.

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body:
> Sorry no, the KDF and XOF's mentioned in this document are _entirely internal_ to the KEM schemes laid out here. These schemes are to be registered in HPKE KEM IANA, and any other HPKE KDF or AEAD usages are fully independent of the schemes laid out here.

A separate document to register SHA3 as an HPKE KDF will probably be useful but that's apart from this one

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body:
> > Sorry no, the KDF and XOF's mentioned in this document are _entirely internal_ to the KEM schemes laid out here. These schemes are to be registered in HPKE KEM IANA, and any other HPKE KDF or AEAD usages are fully independent of the schemes laid out here.
> 
> A separate document to register SHA3 as an HPKE KDF will probably be useful but that's apart from this one

Similarly, X-Wing is registered In IANA as an HPKE KEM. X-Wing uses SHA3 as its KDF and SHAKE256 as an XOF in its key generation/derivation. Those functions are separate from the HPKE KDFs, same with the KEMs defined and registered in this document and the functions they use internally.

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body:
> > > Sorry no, the KDF and XOF's mentioned in this document are _entirely internal_ to the KEM schemes laid out here. These schemes are to be registered in HPKE KEM IANA, and any other HPKE KDF or AEAD usages are fully independent of the schemes laid out here.
> > 
> > 
> > A separate document to register SHA3 as an HPKE KDF will probably be useful but that's apart from this one
> 
> Similarly, X-Wing is registered In IANA as an HPKE KEM. X-Wing uses SHA3 as its KDF and SHAKE256 as an XOF in its key generation/derivation. Those functions are separate from the HPKE KDFs, same with the KEMs defined and registered in this document and the functions they use internally.

@rohanmahy I've created this to register SHA-3 for HPKE KDFs: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-connolly-cfrg-sha3-hpke/

pulls.title: Refactor, cleanup, reorganize
pulls.author: chris-wood
pulls.body: This change refactors some stuff and cleans up the in-lined KEM implementation details.

comments.body:
```suggestion
- `EncapsDerand(pk, randomness) -> (ct, shared_secret)`: A deterministic encapsulation
   algorithm, which takes as input a public encapsulation key `pk` and randomness
   `randomness`, and outputs a ciphertext `ct` and shared secret `shared_secret`.
```

```suggestion
def EncapsDerand(pk, randomness):
  pq_PK = pk[0:1184]
  trad_PK = pk[1184:1217]
  (pq_SS, pq_CT) = ML-KEM-768.EncapsDerand(pq_PK, randomness[0:32])
  ek = randomness[32:65]
  trad_CT = P-256.ScalarMultBase(ek)
  trad_SS = P-256.ScalarMult(ek, trad_PK)
  ss = SHA3-256(pq_SS, trad_SS, trad_CT, trad_PK, label)
  ct = concat(pq_CT, trad_CT)
```

```suggestion
Note that `randomness` MUST be 65 bytes.
```

```suggestion
def EncapsDerand(pk, randomness):
  pq_PK = pk[0:1184]
  trad_PK = pk[1184:1216]
  (pq_SS, pq_CT) = PQ-KEM.EncapsDerand(pq_PK, randomness[0:32])
  ek = randomness[32:64]
```

```suggestion
Note that `randomness` MUST be 64 bytes.
```

```suggestion
def EncapsDerand(pk, randomness):
  pq_PK = pk[0:1568]
  trad_PK = pk[1568:1629]
  (pq_SS, pq_CT) = ML-KEM-1024.EncapsDerand(pq_PK, randomness[0:32])
  ek = randomness[32:80]
  trad_CT = P-384.ScalarMultBase(ek)
  trad_SS = P-384.ScalarMult(ek, trad_PK)
  ss = SHA3-256(pq_SS, trad_SS, trad_CT, trad_PK, label)
  ct = concat(pq_CT, trad_CT)
```

```suggestion
Note that `randomness` MUST be 80 bytes.
```

pulls.title: Preliminary reference implementations and test vectors
pulls.author: chris-wood
pulls.body: This mirrors the spec implementation for X-Wing, but it uses Sage for the NIST curve implementation. (Primarily because I had that laying around from other specs. We can replace with a Python implementation in the future if desired.) It fixes some things in the primary spec around key generation (formatting keys as byte strings), fully specifying the DH operations, etc. It also includes preliminary HPKE KEM codepoint registration requests. And, importantly, adds the test vectors produced from the reference implementation.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @dconnolly I added a `ScalarFromBytes` function, distinct from `DeserializeScalar`, as an infallible constructor that takes bytes and produces `Scalar` values, with an implementation that matches the reference code under the hood. Please take another look!
`%` needs defining above
We could leverage the text above about `Scalar`s and `Element`s to enforce that all instances of `Scalar`s MUST be modulo their order, otherwise they aren't real `Scalar`s

reviews.author: dconnolly
reviews.body: Do we want to enforce the `Scalar` being always modulo its `Order()` via its instantiation? Otherwise we need to define `%` as used in `expandDecapsulationKey` etc

comments.body: That's a cleaner way to handle this. I'll update the textual description of Scalar to include something about mapping from bytes, and say that the bytes are reduced modulo the order, or something.

pulls.title: Update labels to include XOF
pulls.author: chris-wood
pulls.body:
Hopefully these labels are not too terrible on the eyes 🤷 

Closes #4.

comments.body:
```suggestion
2. `KitchenSink-KEM(ML-KEM-768,X25519)-XOF(SHAKE256)-KDF(HKDF-SHA-256)` {{ks-x25519}}:
```

Hm I worry about a comma in a label like this, have we done this in other i*tf crypto protocols? Is it fine in practice?
merging for now, but may want to keep an eye on it

pulls.title: Add generic keygen and derivation
pulls.author: dconnolly
pulls.body: @chris-wood wdyt of the attempt at including slicing of the XOF output into the bytes that go into each component algorithm? 😅

comments.body:
Maybe we replace `Nxofout` with `Npqseed + Ntradseed`? I think the `expanded[..Npqseed]` is fairly clear, but we should probably add some text to the terminology section that describes how it works. Something like:

```
When `x` is a byte string, we use the notation `x[..i]` and `x[i..]` to denote the slice of bytes in `x` starting from the beginning of `x` and leading up to index `i`, including the `i`-th byte, and the slice the bytes in `x` starting from index `i` to the end of `x`, respectively. For example, if `x = [0, 1, 2, 3]`, then `x[..2] = [0, 1]` and `x[2..] = [2, 3]`.
```
Done; can you cross check the numbers for Ntradseed for the p256 and p384 instances?
confirmed out of bad - they are larger than expected  to make sure the Scalar isn't biased (not a power of 2), these match HashToCurve
